p: Rhodiola rosea, a traditional medicinal herb used as stimulant and antidepressant, has great pharmaceutical value including antioxidant, antihypoxic, adaptogenic, cardiovascular, and neuroprotective properties. Its active principals are phenolics (salidroside and p-tyrosol) and glycosides (rosavins) [ 400]. Salidroside and p-tyrosol inhibit the hypoxia-induced endocytosis of pulmonary Na,K-ATPase via the inhibition of the ROS– AMPK–protein kinase Cζ (PKCζ) pathway, signifying the use of Rhodiola as a popular folk medicine for high-altitude illness [ 401]. The mechanisms underlying the potential neuroprotective effects of salidroside involve the regulation of oxidative stress response, inflammation, apoptosis, hypothalamus–pituitary–adrenal axis, neurotransmission, neural regeneration, and the cholinergic system [ 402]. Cui et al. isolated four endophytic fungi from different species of Rhodiola that could produce salidroside and p-tyrosol and characterized P. fortinii as the most capable and stable producer [ 392].
